node.title: The U.S. blacklists the NSO Group, an Israeli spyware firm.
node.alt: An office of the NSO Group in Sapir, Israel.Â The company makes a smartphone surveillance system, Pegasus, that has been under scrutiny.
node.description: NSO and three other companies were added to a list that blocks foreign companies from buying certain types of sensitive American technology without a license.
node.content: ["The Biden administration blacklisted the NSO Group, an Israeli cyber-surveillance company, on Wednesday, saying that the company had supplied spyware that was used by foreign governments to \u201cmaliciously target\u201d government officials, businesspeople, academics and journalists.", "The company makes a sophisticated surveillance system known as Pegasus, which has been under scrutiny for years for its ability to stealthily extract sound recordings, photos, contacts, text messages and other information from targeted smartphones. In July, a consortium of media outlets reported that the app had been used extensively to hack smartphones owned by journalists from India, Morocco, France and elsewhere.", "NSO said in an emailed statement that it was \u201cdismayed by the decision.\u201d", "\u201cOur technologies support U.S. national security interests and policies by preventing terrorism and crime, and thus we will advocate for this decision to be reversed,\u201d the company said.", "NSO and three other companies were added to the so-called Entity List, which blocks foreign companies from buying certain types of sensitive American technology without a license, the Commerce Department\u2019s Bureau of Industry and Security said in an announcement.", "Candiru, an Israeli firm, was sanctioned based on evidence that it had developed and supplied spyware to foreign governments, the Commerce Department said. Positive Technologies of Russia and Computer Security Initiative Consultancy of Singapore were added to the list for trafficking in cybertools that help hackers gain unauthorized access to information systems, the announcement said.", "\u201cThe United States is committed to aggressively using export controls to hold companies accountable that develop, traffic, or use technologies to conduct malicious activities that threaten the cybersecurity of members of civil society, dissidents, government officials and organizations here and abroad,\u201d Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, said in a statement."]
